1. Derek Prince - Breaking Generational Curses 
2. ' Breaking Generational Curses '' # 1 - PASTOR PAULA WHITE - 12/06/12- 7.00 p.m. 
3. Derek Prince: Breaking Generational Curses  2
4. How To Break Generational Bloodline Curses | John Turnipseed on Sid Roth's It's Supernatural! 
5. A prayer for generational curses: ( Generational Blessing prayer)

title: PHILIPPIANS 3 | "IS KNOWING JESUS YOUR HIGHEST PRIORITY?"
description:
Please watch: "The ONE Thing Every Christian Should Be Doing But Most Are NOT!" 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=slK6HI8tUTY --~--
The Priority of Knowing Jesus

Is knowing Jesus Christ the highest priority in your life? Today we‚Äôre gonna continue our study in Philippians chapter 3. 
Hey guys we‚Äôre back for another exciting study in the book of Philippians chapter 3. If you missed the first three videos in this series I encourage you to go back and check those out. 
1. Paul‚Äôs Warning ‚Äì 1-3
a. Paul begins this chapter with a stern warning to his readers to ‚Äúwatch out for those dogs.‚Äù So who is he calling ‚Äúdogs‚Äù and who is he warning his gentile readers. So, understand that when Paul wrote this letter there was this group of Jewish Christians who were following Paul around and teaching Gentiles that in order for them to be saved they had to be circumcised first and obey all of the Jewish laws AND believe in Christ and only then will they be saved. 
b. So Paul warns them and says, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt listen to what they say. You can‚Äôt do anything to earn your salvation
c. So Paul says, ‚ÄúIf you think that external achievements and success can bring you into a relationship with Jesus let me prove it to you by showing you 
d. These guys placed a high emphasis on religious effort and strict adherence to a code of laws. 
e. LESSON: Know the truth well enough to discern truth from error.
2. Paul‚Äôs Testimony ‚Äì 4-6
a. There is nothing outward that we can do that can bring us into an intimate relationship with Jesus Christ. Let me prove it to you‚Ä¶
b. They took so much spiritual pride in their religious pedigree that it forced Paul to rattle off his resume of achievements. 
c. I was circumcised on the 8th day ‚Äì In other words I had godly parents who obeyed God.
d. People of Israel ‚Äì I‚Äôm a member of God‚Äôs chosen people
e. Tribe of Benjamin ‚Äì that was one of the bigger tribes
f. Hebrew of Hebrews ‚Äì I‚Äôm 100% Jewish not mixed with anything
g. Pharisee ‚Äì The highest religious group of Jews. They knew the OT backwards and forwards and took pride in how perfectly they obeyed it. 
h. Righteousness, flawless ‚Äì Paul says, ‚Äúthere has NEVER been a even a blemish on my record.‚Äù Meaning either I obey the law perfectly or when I don‚Äôt I immediately get the right lamb, pigeon, dove or goat to atone for my sins. 
i. But in verse 7 Paul describes his transformation. He says, ‚ÄúBut these assets I have come to regard as liabilities
j. So in other words Paul says, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve lived my entire life thinking that all of these accomplishments and advantages were gaining me favor and earning me points in God‚Äôs economy and now I have to revise my balance sheets because everything I thought was earning me points in God‚Äôs economy actually served to keep me further away from the goal of knowing Jesus Christ. 
k. LESSON: No amount of external success can replace intimacy with God. You can obey the bible, give money to the church, serve in ministry every night of the week, go to seminary and fill your head with a whole lot of theological knowledge and NONE of this replaces intimate time with Jesus. 

3. Paul‚Äôs Pursuit ‚Äì 7-11
a. PERSON ‚Äì Paul says, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt just want to know about Jesus. I don‚Äôt want to sound like I know Him by quoting scriptures and a bunch of Christian clich√©s. I want to know Him intimately, which means both intellectually and experientially. 
b. POWER ‚Äì I want to experience that same power that resurrected Jesus from the dead to be flowing through me. That power is strong enough to resist temptation, break strongholds and addictions in my life, empower me to share my faith when I‚Äôm afraid and don‚Äôt know what to say and empower me to use my gifts when I feel the weakest and most inadequate. 
c. PAIN ‚Äì I‚Äôm even willing to know His pain if that will enable me to be more acquainted with who Jesus is and what He‚Äôs done for me. Most of us aren‚Äôt willing to pray that prayer. 
d. And then Paul goes on to finish by saying that he has not yet attained the intimacy with God that he desires but he presses forward every day to know Jesus more and more. 
e. LESSON: Intimacy with God is a lifelong journey and should be our greatest priority. It should be more important than our careers, our families and even our ministries.

title: HOW TO DEAL WITH CHURCH HURT | I'VE BEEN HURT BY CHURCH!
description:
Please watch: "The ONE Thing Every Christian Should Be Doing But Most Are NOT!" 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=slK6HI8tUTY --~--
see this keywords for video: How to Deal With Church Hurt / how to forgive your church / how to handle church pain, how to heal from church hurt, how to deal with disappointment,

How do you respond when you‚Äôve given your life, your time, and a whole bunch of your money to a church only to be disappointed and hurt?  

INTRODUCTION: I‚Äôve experienced everything from a pastor in college coming on to me to another pastor calling me the N word from the pulpit during his sermon. I personally know other people who have given their hard-earned money to churches and when they were in need whether it was financial or they or their loved ones were sick no one from the church came to visit them or support them and this has left them bitter and angry towards church. So, today I want to give you just a few things to consider if you‚Äôre dealing with church hurt.
1. Don‚Äôt allow a bad experience to cause you to drift
a. When you get hurt by a church you will be strongly tempted to say, ‚ÄúMan forget it!‚Äù and just turn away from God and God‚Äôs people completely. God says, ‚ÄúCall on me IN THE DAY OF TROUBLE. So it‚Äôs in these times when God invites us to draw even closer to Him in prayer. 
b. And so if you find yourself in a season when you‚Äôre not going regularly, it‚Äôs even more important to maintain a regular prayer life and Bible study because I‚Äôm telling you, if not, you can quickly drift away from God.
2. Extend Grace to your Leaders ‚Äì What happens is we put our leaders and pastors on this pedestal and when they disappoint us we become crushed. Understand that they are human too. I don‚Äôt believe there is a more difficult job in the world than being a pastor. And depending on the size of the church it is very easy for a leader to oversee an email, a text message or even a request for help. So know that just because you were hurt by a church, it may not be that it was their intent to do it. 
3. Don‚Äôt judge all Churches by one church
a. It‚Äôs interesting to me that when we get hurt in relationships we eventually find the courage to get into another one and if it‚Äôs a good one we are glad we did because if we didn‚Äôt we would have missed out on the person God meant for us. 
b. In the same way no matter how many bad church experiences you‚Äôve had, keep trying because there is the right church out there for you if you pray, use wisdom and ask God to lead you to it because if you don‚Äôt you could be short-circuiting your own blessings.
4. Bring it to the Church‚Äôs Attention
a. The Bible says we should ‚Äúspeak the truth in love.‚Äù As difficult as it is and no matter how long ago it happened, the only way that church is going to improve is if you are bold enough to sit down with the leaders and clearly communicate your disappointment with them. 
b. When you do that you‚Äôre not only expediting the healing process in your own life but you are also helping the church be aware so that hopefully other people won‚Äôt have to experience the same pain you did.
c. This leads me to my next point. As hurt as you may be‚Ä¶
5. Resist the Urge to Speak Negatively About the Church ‚Äì This is huge. What we are doing without even realizing it is slandering the church or a church leader because of our own personal experience, which in turn could cause someone else to miss out on what God wants to do in and through their life at that church.
6. Forgive those who have hurt you
a. Remember that forgiveness for the Christian is not an option, it‚Äôs a command. You absolutely do not have the choice to remain bitter and unforgiving towards others. 
b. Forgiving them doesn‚Äôt mean that the pain is gone but it means that you can now pray for them, support them and even celebrate their success.

So guys I can‚Äôt tell you how many times I‚Äôve been frustrated, bitter and angry with church or church leaders but I still go, give, support and serve because I know that the church is what Jesus is using to reach the world and I desperately want to be a part of anything that Jesus is building.

see this video other search:
1. how to handle church pain
2. how to heal from church hurt
3. how to deal with disappointment
4. what does it mean to backslide
5. how to forgive your church

title: PHILIPPIANS 2 | "WHAT DOES HUMILITY LOOK LIKE?"
description:
Please watch: "The ONE Thing Every Christian Should Be Doing But Most Are NOT!" 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=slK6HI8tUTY --~--
PHILIPPIANS 2 - What does HUMILITY look like?

Hey everyone welcome back to part 2 of our short series on the book of Philippians. We are taking one chapter a day and choosing a passage of scripture, making some observations and then looking at how we can apply this to our lives. Today we are in chapter 2 and I want to focus on verses 1-11. We are gonna break these 11 verses down into two parts. Verses 1-4 we will call ‚ÄúThe Principle‚Äù and verses 5-11 we will call ‚ÄúThe Picture.‚Äù

1. The Principle (v. 1-4)
a. If you have any encouragement from being a Christian; if you‚Äôve been comforted at all from the love of God, if you have the Spirit in you and if you have any tenderness or compassion in you then have the same mindset that Jesus Christ had. 
b. Do not be selfish; don‚Äôt do things with a selfish motivation
c. Consider others as more important than yourself
d. Don‚Äôt consider only things that are interesting to you but look into what is interesting and important to others.
2. The Picture (v. 5-11)
a. Now Paul says, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve given you the principles but now I want to show you what this looks like by giving you a picture of selflessness and humility.‚Äù  
b. He begins by saying, ‚ÄúIn your relationships with one another, have the same mindset as Christ Jesus.‚Äù So he is encouraging us to apply what we are getting ready to read to all of our relationships such as our family, spouse, children, co-workers, church members, etc. 
c. Mindset #1 ‚Äì Sacrifice ‚Äì ‚Äúrather, He made Himself nothing‚Äù ‚Äì The Bible teaches that Jesus was in heaven, a totally perfect environment. But He chose to sacrifice His perfect environment and position as the son of God to come to earth and be a carpenter. He was willing to give up something that was valuable to Him. 
i. QUESTION: If we say we want to be like Jesus we must challenge ourselves in terms of how willing we are you to sacrifice your time or your money for God and for those we are in relationship with? 
d. Mindset #2 ‚Äì Servant ‚Äì ‚Äúby taking the very nature of a servant‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚Äì It‚Äôs enough that Jesus was willing to sacrifice but He didn‚Äôt come to sit on a throne and have people serve Him. Instead He was always serving others (teaching them, healing them, raising from the dead, feeding them, washing their feet, etc.) 
i. QUESTION: Do I look to be served more than I look for opportunities to serve others? Do I see myself as being above doing certain things when people ask me or do I have the attitude of a servant?
e. Mindset #3 ‚Äì Submission ‚Äì ‚Äúby becoming obedient to death.‚Äù ‚Äì So what we see here is that in order for Jesus to come to earth He first had to be submissive to His Father. Now remember, Jesus is just as much God as God the Father and yet He submitted His will for the will of the Father. 
i. QUESTION: How willing are you to submit to people in relationships (husband, wife at times, your boss, it could be the flight attendant on the plane who tells you to put your laptop away) or do you always have to be the one in control having people submit to you?
f. Mindset #4 ‚Äì Suffering ‚Äì ‚Äúeven death on a cross‚Äù ‚Äì Jesus was willing to suffer so that we might have eternal life. Sometimes we are taught that the Christian life is supposed to be easy but Jesus‚Äô example shows that at times we may have to suffer.
i. QUESTION: How much are you willing to suffer in your relationships with other people?

So, what does it look like to be like Jesus? It involves being willing to sacrifice what‚Äôs valuable to you, serving others, a submissive attitude and a willingness to suffer if need be and the blessing is that it says that God exalted Jesus Christ. And if He rewarded Jesus for having these attitudes I trust He will do the same for you!

title: PROSPERITY GOSPEL EXPOSED!! | Does God Promise Health and Wealth?
description:
Please watch: "The ONE Thing Every Christian Should Be Doing But Most Are NOT!" 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=slK6HI8tUTY --~--
prosperity gospel exposed  Does God promise us health and wealth in the Bible? That‚Äôs our topic today on the BEAT.

Hey everyone, my name is Allen Parr. Here on the BEAT we release a new video every single Tuesday and today we are hitting on one of the most controversial topics out here, ‚ÄúDoes God Promise us Health and Wealth?‚Äù You know the Bible says that in the last days people will flock to teachers who are preaching what their itching ears want to hear.‚Äù But today I want to give you 5 problems that I have with this prosperity gospel. 

1. Inconsistent with the Bible
a. On the contrary God promises that Christians will experience tribulation (Acts 14:22, suffering (Rom. 8:17) and even persecution (2 Tim. 3:12).  
b. The Bible even references ‚Äúbelievers who are poor.‚Äù
c. The Bible says that it‚Äôs not until heaven that God will wipe away our pain, our tears and our sorrow indicating that we can‚Äôt expect ‚Äúour best life‚Äù on earth but rather in eternity.
d. Finally, as you‚Äôve heard me say before, be careful about taking isolated verses or isolated events that happen in scripture and saying that this must be the normative experience for every believer. 

2. Switches the Focus ‚Äì The biggest issue with what is called the prosperity gospel, besides the fact that it is not biblical, is that it switches the focus from what we can and should be doing for God to focusing on what God needs to do for us which puts Him in the place of some spiritual genie who only exists to make us happy. Instead of saying, ‚ÄúGod, in whatever state I find myself, how can I bring the most glory to your name?‚Äù 

3. It sets people up for disappointment with God ‚Äì If churches are telling their members that God has promised them health and wealth then what happens is when that is not their reality or the reality of their loved ones either they are told that they didn‚Äôt have enough faith to receive what God had for them or they are left to believe that God reneged on His promises; neither of which are true.   

4. Limited to the Western World ‚Äì 80% of the world lives on less than $10.00 a day and many of whom are stricken with disease due to lack of clean water and very limited health care. This is not their fault. It‚Äôs just the reality they were born into. So this false teaching sends the message that these Christians who are born in 3rd world countries are somehow less spiritual and less blessed than those who have access to wealth and adequate health care.  

5. This is not consistent with the lives of Jesus and the Apostles
a. The great Apostle Paul admits to having a thorn in his flesh, which most scholars agree was a physical infirmity that limited Paul‚Äôs ministry. 
b. The Bible says that Jesus was a carpenter, which was not considered an affluent career. 
c. It says that he was a traveling preacher who didn‚Äôt have a place to sleep and primarily lived off of the benevolence of others. 
d. Finally it says that His life was characterized by pain, sorrow and ultimately crucifixion.
e. Jesus went on to say that we, His servants, are not above our Master and if they persecuted Him we could expect the same.  

So guys, I‚Äôm not in any way suggesting that God doesn‚Äôt or can‚Äôt heal us or bless us with wealth or that God wants us to be poor, broke down and sick? But what I am suggesting today is that if for whatever reason that becomes our reality God‚Äôs desire is that we glorify Him just as much as we would if we were living in perfect health and wealth. 




Jesus said to beware of false prophets and false teachers. The Bible also says that in the last days people will gather teachers around to hear what their itching ears want to hear. In other words, there will be a mass of people flocking to preachers and teachers who say the very things they desperately want to hear. And who doesn‚Äôt want to hear that they will be healthy and wealthy? And while that sounds good what does the Bible really say?

2. PROSPERITY GOSPEL FULLY EXPOSED
3. PROSPERITY GOSPEL FULLY EXPOSED
4. Exposing The Prosperity Gospel
5. Exposing The Prosperity Gospel

title: PHILIPPIANS 1 | "HOW TO HAVE JOY IN LIFE'S TRIALS"
description:
Please watch: "The ONE Thing Every Christian Should Be Doing But Most Are NOT!" 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=slK6HI8tUTY --~--
And so today I want to make a few observations from chapter 1. 
There are two things that we can learn from Paul that become evident in this passage. First, he was a man of PRAYER.
1. Prayer ‚Äì v. 1-11
a. Consistently (v. 3-4)
b. Specifically
i. Be loving
ii. Increase in their knowledge of God
iii. More depth of insight
iv. Discernment
v. Purity
c. APPLICATION: Do you just pray for people once and then stop or do you pray consistently for them? And when you pray are you lazy with your prayers or do you pray specifically for them like Paul does for the Philippian church? 

And so the first 11 verses are all about PRAYER. But now in verses 12-26 we switch and 

2. Perspective ‚Äì v. 12-26
a. Paul had the right perspective on his PROBLEMS ‚Äì (v.12-13)
i. Paul sees prison not as an OBSTACLE but an OPPORTUNITY ‚Äì 
ii. Instead of feeling sorry for himself and getting mad at God, Paul uses turns his prison cell into a mission field and two things happen.
1. People in Rome hear the gospel and get saved that otherwise would not.
2. Other Christians become more confident to share the gospel after seeing Paul endure and respond to his imprisonment. 
iii. APPLICATION: 
1. Don‚Äôt get so caught up in your own personal prison that you don‚Äôt see the opportunities around you to make a difference in other people‚Äôs lives.
2. People are watching you handle your trials. 
b. Paul had the right perspective on MINISTRY
i. Finally, Paul says in verse 15‚Ä¶
ii. There was a group of Christian preachers who were glad that Paul was in prison because they were jealous of Paul‚Äôs influence and platform and this took the attention off of Paul and gave them the opportunity to develop their own platforms. But even knowing this Paul is like, ‚Äúwhether they preach with good motives or bad motives I ain‚Äôt gonna sweat it because at the end of the day the gospel of Jesus Christ is still being preached!‚Äù 
iii. This teaches us that Paul had a kingdom perspective and not an empire perspective. 
iv. Paul says, ‚ÄúEven though these people are preaching the gospel out of envy thinking they are adding pain to my situation, whether it‚Äôs me or them the main thing is that people are hearing the gospel and people are getting saved. 
c. Paul had the right perspective on his LIFE ‚Äì (v. 21) ‚Äì Paul says in verse 21, ‚ÄúFor me this is a win-win situation. If I live that gives me more time to tell other people about Christ, so I‚Äôm good! If I die then I get to be with Christ in heaven.‚Äù 
i. Paul wasn‚Äôt so connected to his life here on earth that he wasn‚Äôt able to see the bigger picture. 


So guys we are just getting started with this short book I encourage you to read it along with me. I‚Äôd love to hear your observations from chapter 1 or any questions you might have so please leave them in the comments section below. Like this video is you like it, share and don‚Äôt forget to subscribe so you‚Äôll know exactly when a new video is posted.

title: Background to Philippians | BOOK STUDY
description:
Please watch: "The ONE Thing Every Christian Should Be Doing But Most Are NOT!" 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=slK6HI8tUTY --~--
HOOK:  Hey guys I‚Äôm so excited! Today we are going to start our first book study on the BEAT. Stay tuned we‚Äôre gonna jump right in!

INTRODUCTION: Hey everyone, today we are doing something a little different. Over the next four Fridays we are going to be studying the book of Philippians together. 

WHY: Because it‚Äôs a short book. It‚Äôs easy to read. AND it‚Äôs packed with all sorts of application. 

Alright, so any time you study a book of the bible it‚Äôs critical that you check out the background info first. So here we go‚Ä¶

BACKGROUND: 
1. CHURCH: The church at Philippi was founded by the Apostle Paul on his second missionary journey in A.D. 49 (Acts 16:1-40).
2. Somewhere along the line Paul gets thrown in prison.
3. Someone sends word to the church in Philippi that Paul was in prison in Rome
4. WHY? ‚Äì One day while Paul was in prison one of the main leaders of that church named Epaphroditus traveled some 800 miles to bring to Paul three things‚Ä¶
a. A financial gift from the church that he wants to hand deliver from the church
b. Report on how things were going in the church
c. To express the church‚Äôs concern for Paul situation in prison.
5. WHEN ‚Äì And so in response to this visit Paul wrote this letter from prison and sent Epaphroditis back to Philippi to hand deliver his letter to them.  

PURPOSE: SO WHY DID HE WRITE? 
‚Ä¢ To thank them for the financial gift they had given him
‚Ä¢ Provide spiritual wisdom to them as a church
‚Ä¢ To update them on his situation to tell them, ‚Äúhey I‚Äôm in prison. Thank you for the prayers but I‚Äôm doing well.‚Äù
‚Ä¢ He wanted to express his love and concern for this church and let them know that he is praying for them.

THEME: The major theme of the book is JOY! The word joy, rejoice or some form of that word is used 16 times in the book. And so the lesson here is that even though Paul is in prison he wants to demonstrate to his original readers and ultimately to us how it is possible to experience true authentic joy and happiness in spite of your personal circumstances.

SO, your assignment is to read Philippians chapter 1.

title: 3 Lessons We Can Learn From The Rio Olympics
description:
Please watch: "The ONE Thing Every Christian Should Be Doing But Most Are NOT!" 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=slK6HI8tUTY --~--
3 Lessons We Can Learn From The Rio Olympics

If God were to award a gold medal, how can we be sure we would win?

INTRODUCTION: Hey everyone, my name is Allen Parr thank you so much for joining me today. Every Tuesday we release a new video and this week is the second week of the 2016 Olympics and if you‚Äôre anything like me you‚Äôve been glued to the TV watching all sorts of sports you would normally not watch just because it is Olympic season! So today I want to take a look at three qualities we desperately need to possess to win God‚Äôs gold medal. 

BACKGROUND: In the city of Corinth every two years they hosted something very similar to the Olympic Games. So, knowing his audience is well familiar with athletics Paul uses this analogy and gives us three things to consider about rewards.  

1. Determination ‚Äì 1 Cor. 9:24
a. What makes Olympic athletes so great is that they don‚Äôt allow injuries, failures or haters deter them from reaching their goal. 
b. Mo Farrah fell down, got back up and still won his race. What‚Äôs the lesson?  
c. So, in the same way if we want to win we cannot allow fear, fatigue failure, distractions, discouragements, or disappointments or any other temporary setback to derail you from fulfilling God‚Äôs purpose for your life. 
d. Why? 
e. Because Paul says Olympians do all of this for rewards that will eventually perish. But the rewards we get for God last for all eternity which is why we should always focus more on our calling than we do our career.  
2. Discipline
a. You can be determined and have all the passion in the world but you won‚Äôt win in life unless you have discipline. 
b. Paul is saying that these athletes train several hours a day to be great. 
c. You must be willing to put in the time every day to work on your business, craft, your gift, your idea, etc.  
i. What do you want to accomplish? (write it down, make it clear, be specific, set goals, time frames, etc.) ‚Äì VISION
ii. How do you get there? STRATEGY
iii. And how will you know if you got there? ASSESSMENT
d. Every day you should be doing something relates back to one of those questions. 
e. This leads to my 3rd point which is‚Ä¶.
3. Direction
a. Notice that gymnasts aren‚Äôt trying to be swimmers and 
b. In the same way if we want to win we need to find that one thing that we know God has called us to and then give ourselves COMPLETELY to it. 
c. How do you do that? 
d. Let me give you three questions to point you in the right direction. 
i. What gifts do you have?
ii. What pain in your past can you help other people work through?
iii. What have other people consistently affirmed in your life?
e. The more things you are trying to be great at and focus on the less effective you‚Äôll be for all of them. 

Now I wish the passage ended there but there is a fourth D and that is DISQUALIFICATION. So Paul says that if we don‚Äôt discipline our bodies to exercise self-control and to deny our fleshly desires we can sadly be disqualified from receiving God‚Äôs best for our lives.

title: Marriage Killers | Things that will Destroy Your Marriage
description:
Please watch: "The ONE Thing Every Christian Should Be Doing But Most Are NOT!" 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=slK6HI8tUTY --~--
Do you know what destroys marriages? Stick around and find out!

Hey everyone my name is Allen Parr thank you so much for hanging out with me today. Here on the BEAT we release a new video every Tuesday and today we are talking about things that destroy our marriages!

We‚Äôre are going to take a look at one of my favorite passages of scripture Eph. 4:25-29. The context here is that Paul is describing what he calls the old man, which refers to our old way of thinking and living BEFORE CHRIST, with our new man, which refers to who we are now that we have the Spirit of God living within us. And so he begins to list several things that should not be a part of our new nature. And so I want to give you three things from this passage that will absolutely destroy your marriage. 

1. Dishonesty ‚Äì Eph. 4:25 ‚Äì Paul says, ‚ÄúTherefore each of you must put off FALSEHOOD and speak truth to your neighbor.‚Äù
a. Exaggerating
b. Making excuses to save face when we are caught doing something we didn‚Äôt think the other person knew about
c. Making False promises
d. Not following through
e. Lying
f. Damages trust and remember that trust takes years to build, seconds to break and forever to repair. 

2. Anger ‚Äì Eph. 4:26
a. Notice Paul says here to ‚ÄúBE ANGRY.‚Äù He‚Äôs not suggesting that we never get angry but rather that we don‚Äôt sin when we get angry. How do we do that? 
b. One of the ways is to remain angry and refuse to resolve the conflict. 
c. Paul gives us a time frame in which to resolve it (not to be taken literally) which is by the end of one day.
d. Then more importantly he tells us why we should resolve conflict quickly. It‚Äôs because when we don‚Äôt we are giving the devil an opportunity to tempt us to hold a grudge, harbor unforgiveness, become bitter and think negative thoughts about the other person. 
e. Remember the principle. When you and your spouse aren‚Äôt talking to each other, the devil is speaking to both of you. 

3. Unhealthy Communication
a. Notice four things here. First, Paul describes it as unwholesome which could refer to criticism, cursing, outbursts of anger, being judgmental, etc. Any of that kills your marriage. 
b. Second, be careful to use our words that build each other up. 
c. Third, it says ‚Äúaccording to the need of the moment‚Äù meaning we need to discern not just what we say but when we say it. [TIMING IS EVERYTHING].
d. Finally, the tone we use when we say it, ‚Äúhe says it should give ‚Äògrace‚Äô to those who hear.‚Äù Some of us have some really good things to say but because our tone and our timing is off it‚Äôs not received. 

4. Unforgiveness - Notice Paul says here, "To forgive JUST AS Christ has forgiven you."

So if you‚Äôre dating, engaged, married or in any type of relationship you value I pray that will replace dishonesty with integrity, anger with conflict resolution and unhealthy communication with encouragement, affirmation and speaking positive things into the life of your partner. You start doing that and I trust that our relationships will be what God intended for them to be.

title: Does The Bible Support Slavery?
description:
Please watch: "The ONE Thing Every Christian Should Be Doing But Most Are NOT!" 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=slK6HI8tUTY --~--
DOES THE BIBLE SUPPORT SLAVERY?

During the darkest era in the history of our country Christian slave owners would use the Bible to support slavery. But is that what the Bible teaches?

Hey everyone, my name is Allen Parr thank you so much for visiting my channel. Here on the BEAT we release a new video every single Tuesday and today we are touching on a very controversial and misunderstood topic, which is, ‚ÄúDoes the Bible Support Slavery?‚Äù And so in this video I want so share with you 7 facts about slavery in the Bible.  

Understand that slavery in the Bible was not the same as it was in our country

1. God Did Not Establish Slavery but Regulated it
a. In other words just as there are laws on murder, divorce and theft (all things God clearly does not condone), God also knew the hearts of people were evil and had to establish laws to regulate slavery to ensure that slaves were treated properly. 
b. Actually the exact opposite is true. God only creates laws to regulate evil not good. 
2. The Purpose of Slavery 
a. The purpose of slavery in the Bible was the help the poor survive.
b. This is the exact opposite of what our country practiced for nearly 400 years. This leads‚Ä¶
3. In the Hebrew culture slavery was primarily volitional ‚Äì Lev. 25:39
a. The most common way a person became a slave was if they were in debt. They would either sell themselves or their children‚Äôs services to pay off the debt ‚Äì Lev. 25:39
b. Others would choose to be slaves to have all of their basic needs met by their master. These are called ‚Äúbondservants‚Äù ‚Äì Exodus 21:5-6. This leads to the next point which is‚Ä¶ 
4. Kidnapping was outlawed and punishable by DEATH ‚Äì Ex. 21:16 (see also 1 Tim. 1:10) ‚Äì Taking someone against their will and making them your slave was against the law and the will of God. 
5. Slavery was limited to 6 years ‚Äì Ex. 21:2
a. It was never God‚Äôs will for the rich to overtake the poor. 
b. On the contrary this system allowed for people to work off their debt in a safe and loving environment. However, after 6 years the slave would go free and the master was commanded to give something to them and send them on their way which is contrasted to what our country practiced. This leads me to my sixth point‚Ä¶
6. Slave masters were to treat slaves with respect
a. They were commanded to treat them as ‚Äúemployees‚Äù and not as slaves ‚Äì Lev. 25:39.
b. If they killed their slaves they themselves would face punishment ‚Äì Ex. 21:20
c. One of the ways to do this was to maintain the family unit which is a principle slave owners in America violated ‚Äì Lev. 25:41; Ex. 21:3
d. Finally, a master was buying the services not the servant. God was very clear that no man can ‚Äúown‚Äù another man because we were created in God‚Äôs image and everyone belongs to God ‚Äì Lev. 25:55.
7. Slavery was not based on race ‚Äì Nowhere in the Bible does it condone enslaving a race of people only individuals on a voluntary basis. 

So, does the Bible make concessions for and have laws that regulate the practice of slavery? I‚Äôd have to say yes it does. Does it support the degradation and mistreatment of slaves as was practiced in our country? NO it does not. 
I‚Äôll leave two links below in the comments section

FOR FURTHER READING: https://answersingenesis.org/bible-questions/doesnt-the-bible-support-slavery/

And...

http://www.compellingtruth.org/slavery-Old-Testament.html

title: Seven Reasons Why We Need the Holy Spirit
description:
Please watch: "The ONE Thing Every Christian Should Be Doing But Most Are NOT!" 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=slK6HI8tUTY --~--
WHO IS THE HOLY SPIRIT?

We know about God the Father. We know what Jesus did on the cross. But who is the Holy Spirit?  Who is the Holy Spirit and what role does He play in our lives? 

Hey everyone, my name is Allen Parr thank you so much for visiting my channel. And today we are answering the question, ‚ÄúWho is the Holy Spirit?‚Äù And ‚ÄúWhat role does He Play in my life?‚Äù So, I want to give you 7 things the Holy Spirit actively does in your life but beforehand I want to point out two disclaimers. 

DISCLAIMERS
1. The Holy Spirit is not an ‚Äúit‚Äù or a ‚Äúforce‚Äù ‚Äì The Holy Spirit is the 3rd person of the trinity. This means that we should not refer to Him as an it, like He‚Äôs some force (may the force be with you). The Bible says we can grieve Him, quench Him and we can lie to Him, He talks to us, etc. The Holy Spirit is just as much God as God the Father and God the Son but has a different role or function. God the Father is the source of all things. Jesus was sent to die on the cross for our sins and the Holy Spirit has several functions that we will discussion.  
2. You don‚Äôt have to wait for Him, tarry for Him or pray to get Him, God gives Him to indwell every believer at the moment of salvation. 1 Cor. 12:7; 

WHAT DOES HE DO?
1. Salvation ‚Äì The first role He plays in your life occurs before salvation. He is the One that is working on your heart convincing you that you are a sinner in need of total forgiveness. That need for something beyond what this world is offering is ignited within you by the Holy Spirit. 

2. Convicts us ‚Äì John 14:26; John 16:8-11 ‚Äì One of His main roles is to act as a warning light and convict us when we get off track. This is the reason why you can still sin after you get saved but you just can‚Äôt enjoy your sin anymore because now the Holy Spirit Who lives within you is constantly convicting you. He does this primarily by reminding you of what God‚Äôs will is for your life. Before you sin He will remind you. After you sin He will convict you.

3. Teaches us ‚Äì John 14:26 ‚Äì When you are studying the Bible one of His jobs is to pull the scales off of your eyes and teach you what the Bible is saying and help you apply it to your life. Theologians call this ‚Äúillumination‚Äù the process by which God shines His light on the word of God and applies it to your spirit specifically for where you are at that moment. We call this illumination when God opens your eyes to understand His word in a way you‚Äôve never understood it before and then to apply it to your life so that it goes from your head (where you understand it) to your heart (where you believe it) and finally to your hands (where you live it out). 

4. Reminds you ‚Äì The Bible says, ‚ÄúHe will bring back to your remembrance‚Ä¶‚Äù God can‚Äôt bring back to your remembrance something that was never there! Which is why it‚Äôs critical that you get into the word of God because it is from your spiritual reservoir that the Spirit will draw from when you need to know God‚Äôs perspective on something whether it may be temptation or a decision you need to make. This is why you never need to be afraid of sharing your faith because He has promised to give you the right things to say at that time. 

5. Counselor ‚Äì The Holy Spirit acts as a counselor and a guide throughout life. In other words He helps us make wise decisions. For instance when you‚Äôre in a heated debate you will often hear Him say, ‚ÄúSay that!‚Äù or ‚ÄúNo, don‚Äôt say that!‚Äù 

6. Produces Fruit ‚Äì Gal. 5:16 ‚Äì Finally, the longer you are a Christian the more fruit the Holy Spirit will enable you to bear. One of His main functions is to help you live out and increase in this fruit every day.

7. Empowers you to use your Spiritual Gifts ‚Äì Acts 1:8 ‚Äì The Holy Spirit infuses you with power especially when you are feeling inadequate and enables you to use your gifts on a level outside of your normal strength. 

So, between God the Father, God the Son and God the Holy Spirit the Holy Spirit is the most overlooked and often misunderstood member of the trinity and yet He does the most hands-on work in terms of making us look more like Jesus every day.

title: How to Know if You're Unequally Yoked
description:
Please watch: "The ONE Thing Every Christian Should Be Doing But Most Are NOT!" 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=slK6HI8tUTY --~--
What does it mean to be unequally yoked? That‚Äôs coming up next on the BEAT.

Hey everyone my name is Allen Parr thank you so much for visiting my channel. Here on the BEAT we release a new video every Tuesday and today we are answering the question, ‚ÄúWhat does it mean‚Äù or ‚Äúwhat does it look like to be unequally yoked?‚Äù This idea comes from 2 Cor. 6:14 where Paul says, ‚ÄúDo not be unequally yoked together with unbelievers.‚Äù So today I want to talk about what that means and then give you four ways you can tell you‚Äôre in an unequally yoked relationship. 

CONCEPT: Paul uses the imagery of two oxen whose necks are connected to one another with a yoke. Farmers would ‚Äúyoke‚Äù animals together to plow fields or carry heavy loads. They were taught never to yoke together say a horse with an ox because they differed in size, strength, purpose and capacity. So because they are connected with a yoke, one of the animals would overtake and control the other taking it in the wrong direction resulting in the field never getting plowed. 

1. Different Spiritual Maturity 
a. I‚Äôm talking more specifically to the women here because you‚Äôll often see a woman in church without her husband but you‚Äôll rarely see a man in church without his family if he is a spiritual leader. 
b. You‚Äôre gonna find yourself consistently caught between obeying God and submitting to your husband. 
c. Either you‚Äôre gonna grow spiritually which means you won‚Äôt be able to share the most important part of you with your husband because he won‚Äôt be able to understand. Your with someone who can‚Äôt even relate to the most important part of you. 
d. Or what normally happens is your spiritual growth will be stunted because of his. 
e. Can your mate eventually come around and be the spiritual leader you desire? Yes, but it‚Äôs rare and we are advised to avoid such cases. 
f. Now there is one exception here and that is if the man is 1) showing tangible signs of investing in his spiritual growth and 2) Teachable
2. Different Values
a. MONEY ‚Äì You want to give money to the church; they want to buy new furniture
b. CHURCH INVOLVEMENT ‚Äì You want to serve in church; they think you‚Äôre at the church too much
c. You want to go to church together; they would rather stay home
d. DECISION MAKING ‚Äì You believe the bible is the final authority on making decisions. They believe it‚Äôs an old antiquated book with no relevance. They have a different way of making decisions. 
e. PRAYER ‚Äì You want to pray together. They don‚Äôt see the point or don‚Äôt know how. 
f. You want to use vacation to go on a missions trip; they don‚Äôt see the value
g. RAISING KIDS ‚Äì Raising Kids
h. MORALS ‚Äì When someone consistently pressures or tempts you to go against what you morally believe is wrong you‚Äôre unequally yoked.
i. All of these different values can cause friction and tension and ultimately break down the relationship. 
3. Different Purposes
a. I‚Äôm not talking about two Christians who have different purposes but both of them are under the umbrella of Christian service. 
b. I‚Äôm not moreso about one person who feels called to Christian service and the other feels called to corporate, entertainment, sports, etc. 
c. Both of them are going to give all their time, energy, passion and money to what they feel called to and eventually their paths will take them in different directions creating tension and friction in the relationship. 
d. Or at some point one of them is going to have to sacrifice what they feel ‚Äúcalled‚Äù to for the good of the relationship which often times leads to deep-seated resentment. 


So can two Christians be unequally yoked? Well, the Bible nowhere discourages us from marrying another Christian. However, the bigger the gap in spiritual maturity the more differences you‚Äôll have to work through in marriage.

title: Three Ways to Measure Spiritual Growth
description:
Please watch: "The ONE Thing Every Christian Should Be Doing But Most Are NOT!" 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=slK6HI8tUTY --~--
How can you know that you are growing spiritually?

Hey everyone welcome back my name is Allen Parr thank you so much for visiting my channel. Here on the BEAT we release a new video every Tuesday and today I want to give you 3 questions that I want to encourage you to ask yourself regularly to be sure that you are growing spiritually and they come from Hebrews 5:12-15. And the first is‚Ä¶

1. AM I A CONSUMER OR A CONTRIBUTOR? (v. 12a)
a. Notice the writer says, ‚Äúby this time you ought to be teachers‚Ä¶‚Äù 
b. The Greek word for time is ‚Äúchronos‚Äù which refers to a span of time. The Greek word for ‚Äúought‚Äù means ‚Äúobligation.‚Äù  
c. So he is essentially saying, ‚Äúbecause of the amount of time that has elapsed since you‚Äôve been a Christian you are obligated to now be teaching others.‚Äù 
d. So my question is, ‚ÄúAm I coming to church every week primarily to consume or am I contributing by teaching others and sharing my wisdom, experiences, successes, failures and contributing to the disciple-making process? 
e. And so the first way to know you are growing spiritually is if you are actively making disciples and pouring yourself into someone else. 
2. AM I EATING MEAT OR DRINKING MILK?
a. Notice he says, ‚ÄúYou need milk; not solid food. For everyone who lives on milk is unskilled in the word of righteousness, since he is a child.‚Äù
b. Milk demonstrates dependence. In the same way that a baby needs their mother for milk a young baby Christian cannot feed themselves independently from their pastors and teachers. 
c. Milk is a picture of the elementary teachings about the Christian faith (v. 12). It‚Äôs what every baby needs in order to grow. What the author is saying is that‚Äôs good at the beginning of your walk as a Christian. But there comes a time in the natural course of spiritual growth that you should become interested in learning the deeper aspects of the Christian faith which by the way will help you become more equipped to be a contributor rather than a consumer.
d. Finally milk is pre-digested food. By the time you get to church that pastor has already eaten, chewed on and digested that food and is ready to give it to you. God wants you to have the same experience the pastors and teachers are having. He wants to give you fresh food and a fresh revelation for yourself. 
3. AM I ABLE TO DISCERN TRUTH FROM ERROR?
a. Notice he says, ‚ÄúBut solid food is for the mature, for those who have their powers of discernment trained by CONSTANT PRACTICE to distinguish good from evil.‚Äù 
b. Am I able to spot false teaching when I hear it? Notice that the writer says the ONLY way to do this is by ‚Äúconstant use‚Äù or ‚Äúpractice.‚Äù There are so many false teachings in our churches today. 
c. And the best way to spot a counterfeit bill is not to study all of the counterfeit bills but rather to study the true dollar bill so that anything you see that is different you automatically know is counterfeit.
d. If you want to be discerning don‚Äôt spend time studying other religions. Study the word of God and then you‚Äôll be able to quickly discern truth from error because when we don‚Äôt do this‚Ä¶
e. Paul says that when we do not have discernment we are ‚Äúlike infants tossed back and forth by every wind of doctrine .‚Äù [a baby will put anything in its mouth]
f. Your ability to discern false teaching when you hear it is an indication that you are growing spiritually.

Hey guys I talk about this subject a lot on my channel because I am convinced that Bible study is the primary way a Christian grows spiritually. I‚Äôve written some blogs, eBooks and done some videos all designed to maximize your understanding of God‚Äôs word that I believe you‚Äôll find helpful. I‚Äôll leave the links in the comments section below. I‚Äôd love to hear which of these three questions you are struggling with personally leave it in the comments section below.
